Improving the Sampling Strategy in KernelSHAP

Lars Henry Berge Olsen E-mail address to corresponding author: lholsen@math.uio.no. Department of Mathematics, University of Oslo Martin Jullum Norwegian Computing Center
(October 7, 2024)
Abstract

Shapley values are a popular model-agnostic explanation framework for explaining predictions made by complex machine learning models. The framework provides feature contribution scores that sum to the predicted response and represent each feature’s importance. The computation of exact Shapley values is computationally expensive due to estimating an exponential amount of non-trivial conditional expectations. The KernelSHAP framework enables us to approximate the Shapley values using a sampled subset of weighted conditional expectations. We propose three main novel contributions: a stabilizing technique to reduce the variance of the weights in the current state-of-the-art strategy, a novel weighing scheme that corrects the Shapley kernel weights based on sampled subsets, and a straightforward strategy that includes the important subsets and integrates them with the corrected Shapley kernel weights. We compare these new approximation strategies against existing ones by evaluating their Shapley value accuracy as a function of the number of subsets. The results demonstrate that our sampling strategies significantly enhance the accuracy of the approximated Shapley value explanations, making them more reliable in practical applications. This work provides valuable insights and practical recommendations for researchers and practitioners seeking to implement Shapley value-based explainability of their models.

Keywords: Explainable artificial intelligence, Shapley values, model-agnostic explanation, prediction explanation, feature dependence

1 Introduction

The field of Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) has developed various explanation frameworks to provide insights into the inner workings of complex models and to make their predictions more understandable to humans \parenciteadadi2018peeking, covert2021explaining, molnar2019. Developing and adopting XAI frameworks is crucial for bridging the gap between model complexity and transparency, trustworthiness, and explainability. When properly used, XAI can foster better decision-making, ensure compliance with regulatory standards, and facilitate model debugging by enabling practitioners/stakeholders to comprehend their model’s decision-making process \parenciteebers2020regulating, schwalbe2023comprehensive. As machine learning continues to evolve, the role of XAI will become increasingly important in ensuring that the benefits of advanced models are harnessed responsibly and effectively. One of the most used explanation frameworks is Shapley values \parenciteshapley1953value, molnar2023SHAP.

Shapley values stem from cooperative game theory but are in the context of XAI, often used as a post-hoc model-agnostic local explanation framework that explains the prediction f⁢(𝒙)𝑓𝒙f(\boldsymbol{x})italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) made by a complex model f𝑓fitalic_f. Post-hoc means that the explanations are made after the model has been trained and its predictions made. That is, the explanations are not inherently built into the model but are derived from its behavior. Model-agnostic means that we can explain any model f𝑓fitalic_f, and local means that we explain the prediction of a single observation 𝒙𝒙\boldsymbol{x}bold_italic_x called the explicand. The explanation is a vector of feature contributions ϕbold-italic-ϕ\boldsymbol{\phi}bold_italic_ϕ that sums to the predicted response.

In this paper, we consider the setting of supervised learning and provide Shapley values to explain a predictive model f⁢(𝒙)𝑓𝒙f(\boldsymbol{x})italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) trained on 𝒳={𝒙[i],y[i]}i=1Ntrain𝒳superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒙delimited-[]𝑖superscript𝑦delimited-[]𝑖𝑖1subscript𝑁train\mathcal{X}=\{\boldsymbol{x}^{[i]},y^{[i]}\}_{i=1}^{N_{\text{train}}}caligraphic_X = { bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_i ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_i ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT train end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Here 𝒙[i]superscript𝒙delimited-[]𝑖\boldsymbol{x}^{[i]}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_i ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an M𝑀Mitalic_M-dimensional feature vector, y[i]superscript𝑦delimited-[]𝑖y^{[i]}italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_i ] end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a univariate response, and Ntrainsubscript𝑁trainN_{\text{train}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT train end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the number of training observations. However, Shapley values can be extended to provide global explanations, i.e., explaining global model effects across all observations \parenciteowen2014sobol, covert2020understanding, frye_shapley-based_2020, and to other domains: images \parencitefastshap, text \parencitechen2018shapley, graphs \parencitewang2021shapley, duval2021graphsvx, and series of models \parencitechen2022explaining. \textcitemolnar2019 provides a detailed overview and introduction to other explanation frameworks such as accumulated local effects, local interpretable model-agnostic explanations, and counterfactual explanations.

We focus on conditional Shapley values, which incorporates feature dependencies into the explanations \parenciteaas2019explaining. This is in contrast to marginal Shapley values where one omits the dependencies. The two versions coincide when there are no dependencies between features, and the methods proposed in this paper also apply to marginal Shapley values. The conditional Shapley values are consistent with standard probability axioms \parencite[Proposition 7]covert2021explaining, but this consistency comes at the cost of increased computational complexity due to the necessity of modeling dependencies between arbitrary feature combinations. Throughout this article, we refer to conditional Shapley values when discussing Shapley values unless otherwise specified.

In general, computing Shapley values is an NP-hard problem \parencitedeng1994complexity, faigle1992shapley, and the direct computations are exponential in the number of features M𝑀Mitalic_M. A wide range of approximation strategies have been proposed, which are either based on model assumptions (making the explanations model-specific) or model-agnostic methods that use stochastic, sampling-based estimators that are correct in expectation. The model-agnostic methods are connected to different but equivalent formulations of Shapley values. Shapley values can be viewed as a semivalue \parencitecastro2009polynomial, least squares value \parencitecharnes1988extremal, random order value \parencitemonderer2002variations, or a multilinear extension \parenciteOwenMulti. See \textcitechen2023algorithms for a more in-depth introduction to these Shapley value formulations.

We compute Shapley values by solving a weighted least squares problem, thus focusing on approximation strategies tied to the least squares value formulation. More specifically, we propose enhancements to the KernelSHAP approximation framework \parencitelundberg2017unified and the current state-of-the-art strategy \parencitecovert2021explaining to lower the computational complexity and improve the tractability. KernelSHAP approximates Shapely values using a (weighted) subset of the exponential number of feature combinations. We introduce novel strategies to select and weigh the elements of this subset using stabilizing techniques and corrected Shapley kernel values based on the sampled subset.

Section 2 introduces the Shapley value explanation framework and how to compute them exactly and approximate them using the KernelSHAP framework. Section 3 discusses the current state-of-the-art approximation strategies and our novel extensions and strategies. Section 4 presents numerical simulation studies comparing the accuracy of the different approximation strategies, while Section 5 conducts experiments on real-world data. Finally, Section 6 provides conclusions and outlines further work. The Appendix includes implementation details, other strategies, and additional information.

2 Shapley Values

The conditional expectation summarizes the whole probability distribution, it is the most common estimator in prediction applications, and it is also the minimizer of the commonly used squared error loss function \parenciteaas2019explaining. Computing (2) is not straightforward for a general data distribution and model. Assuming independent features, or having f𝑓fitalic_f be linear, simplifies the computations \parencitelundberg2017unified, aas2019explaining, but these assumptions do not generally hold. There is a wide range of methods used to estimate v⁢(𝒮)𝑣𝒮v({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ), using, e.g., Gaussian assumptions \parencitechen2020true, aas2019explaining, conditional inference trees \parenciteredelmeier2020, or variational auto-encoders \parenciteOlsen2022. \textciteolsen2024comparative provides an extensive overview of the methods and categorizes them according to whether they use Monte Carlo integration or regression to estimate the contribution function.

In the simulation studies in Section 4, we generate data from the multivariate Gaussian distribution. To obtain accurate conditional Shapley values, we need to generate Monte Carlo samples that follow the true conditional distribution of the data.

2.1 Approximation Strategies

In this section, we highlight procedures that use approximations or model assumptions to reduce the computational complexity of the Shapley value explanation framework and make the computations tractable in higher dimensions. The approximative speed-up strategies can be divided into model-specific and model-agnostic strategies \parencitechen2023algorithms.

The model-specific strategies put assumptions on the predictive model f𝑓fitalic_f to improve the computational cost, but some of the strategies are restricted to marginal Shapley values. For conditional Shapley values, \textciteaas2019explaining,chen2020true derive explicit expressions for linear models to speed up the computations, and \textcitelundberg2020local proposes the path-dependent TreeSHAP algorithm for tree-based models. \textciteyang2021fast improves the speed of the TreeSHAP algorithm by pre-computing expensive steps at the cost of a slightly higher memory consumption. While \textcitebifet2022linear reduce the time complexity from polynomial to linear time with their Linear TreeSHAP algorithm and \textcitemuschalik2024beyond extend it to any-order Shapley interaction index scores \parencitegrabisch1999axiomatic. There are also speed-up strategies for deep neural network models, but they are limited to marginal Shapley values \parenciteancona2019explaining, wang2020shapley.

The model-agnostic strategies put no assumptions on the predictive model f𝑓fitalic_f and often use stochastic sampling-based estimators \parenciteaas2019explaining, lundberg2017unified, okhrati2021multilinear, mitchell2022sampling. That is, to speed up the computations, they approximate the Shapley value explanations by a sampled subset of the coalitions instead of considering the exponential amount of them. Thus, the strategies are stochastic; however, their expectations are unbiased. One of the most common model-agnostic strategies is the KernelSHAP strategy introduced in \textcitelundberg2017unified and improved by \textcitecovert2021improving. In the KernelSHAP strategy, we sample, e.g., N𝒮<2Msubscript𝑁𝒮superscript2𝑀N_{\mathcal{S}}<2^{M}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT coalitions and use only these coalitions to approximate the Shapley value explanations using the least squares value formulation. This strategy enables us to approximate the explanations in tractable time even for large values of M𝑀Mitalic_M; however, an N𝒮≪2Mmuch-less-thansubscript𝑁𝒮superscript2𝑀N_{\mathcal{S}}\ll 2^{M}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≪ 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will (likely) produce poor approximations.

There exist other approximation strategies linked to alternative Shapley formulations, such as the permutation sampling-based frameworks based on the random order value formulation \parencitestrumbelj2010efficient, strumbelj2014explaining, chen2022algorithms. We prefer the KernelSHAP framework over permutation sampling-based frameworks due to its superior efficiency. In the context of conditional Shapley values, the primary computational burden is related to the number of v⁢(𝒮)𝑣𝒮v({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) values that need to be calculated. KernelSHAP leverages all computed v⁢(𝒮)𝑣𝒮v({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) values to determine the Shapley values for all features. In contrast, permutation sampling only uses a portion of the evaluated v⁢(𝒮)𝑣𝒮v({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) values to estimate each feature’s Shapley value, resulting in less efficient utilization of these values. Examples of approximation strategies for the permutation sampling-based framework include orthogonal spherical codes \parencitemitchell2022sampling, stratified sampling \parencitecastro2017improving, maleki2015addressing, paired sampling \parencitecovert2021improving, mitchell2022sampling, and many others \parencitemitchell2022sampling, van2018new, illes2019estimation. However, these strategies typically cannot be directly integrated into the KernelSHAP approximation framework and are thus considered outside the scope of this article.

We refer to \textcitechen2023algorithms for more details about the model-agnostic and model-specific strategies. \textcitefastshap propose to sidestep the Shapley value formula by training a black-box neural network to directly output the Shapley value explanations, while \textcitejullum2021groupshapley explain groups of similar/correlated features instead of individual features to reduce the computations.

A common solution is to approximate the Shapley values by solving (4) using a sampled subset of coalitions 𝒟⊆𝒫⁢(ℳ)𝒟𝒫ℳ{\mathcal{D}}\subseteq{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{M}})caligraphic_D ⊆ caligraphic_P ( caligraphic_M ) (with replacement) instead of all coalitions 𝒮∈𝒫⁢(ℳ)𝒮𝒫ℳ{\mathcal{S}}\in{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{M}})caligraphic_S ∈ caligraphic_P ( caligraphic_M ). This framework is called KernelSHAP \parencitelundberg2017unified, and the coalitions are sampled from a distribution following the Shapley kernel weights in (6). Thus, the sampled subsets are weighted equally in the new weighted least squares problem, while the empty and grand coalitions are always included and exempt from the sampling. The KernelSHAP framework is also useful in lower dimensions if v⁢(𝒮)𝑣𝒮v({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) is expensive to compute. \textcitewilliamson2020efficient shows that the KernelSHAP approximation framework is consistent and asymptotically unbiased, while \textcitecovert2021improving shows that it is empirically unbiased for even a modest number of coalitions.

3 Sampling Strategies

In this section, we describe established and novel strategies for selecting the N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT unique coalitions in 𝒟𝒟{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D and how to weigh them in (7) when approximating Shapley value explanations. We provide an overview of the strategies and their characteristic properties in Table 1. The empty and grand coalitions are always included in the approximations; thus, they are excluded from the sampling procedure. Consequently, N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an integer between (exclusive) 2222 and 2Msuperscript2𝑀2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, as the full set of coalitions yields exact Shapley values. In Appendix E, we discuss alternative strategies that were investigated but performed worse. In Appendix G, we demonstrate that our novel techniques can significantly enhance the strategy used in the SHAP Python library \parenciteshap_python.

In Figures 1 and 2, we illustrate the weights used in (7) by the strategies introduced below when normalized over the N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT unique coalitions in 𝒟𝒟{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D. Figure 1 focuses on an M=10𝑀10M=10italic_M = 10-dimensional setting with N𝒮∈{100,250,750,1000}subscript𝑁𝒮1002507501000N_{\mathcal{S}}\in\{100,250,750,1000\}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ { 100 , 250 , 750 , 1000 }. We index the coalitions by first ordering them based on coalition size, i.e., {1}1\{1\}{ 1 } precedes {1,2}12\{1,2\}{ 1 , 2 }, and then by their elements for equal-sized coalitions, i.e., {1,2}12\{1,2\}{ 1 , 2 } precedes {1,3}13\{1,3\}{ 1 , 3 }. This indexing ensures that coalitions with indices i𝑖iitalic_i and 2M+1−isuperscript2𝑀1𝑖2^{M}+1-i2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 - italic_i are complementary, for i=1,2,…,2M𝑖12…superscript2𝑀i=1,2,\dots,2^{M}italic_i = 1 , 2 , … , 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, as seen by the paired strategy’s weights being symmetric around the dashed vertical lines in Figure 1. The weights of the empty (i=1𝑖1i=1italic_i = 1) and grand (i=2M=1024𝑖superscript2𝑀1024i=2^{M}=1024italic_i = 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1024) coalitions are omitted as they are strategy-independent and infinite.

3.2 Paired

The paired strategy improves the unique strategy by using a variance reduction technique for Monte Carlo methods called paired sampling333Also called antithetic and halved sampling in the literature \parencitechen2023algorithms. \parencite[Ch. 9]kroese2013handbook. \textcitecovert2021improving demonstrates that paired sampling reduces the variance of the Shapley values approximations compared to the unique strategy. The paired sampling strategy pairs each sampled coalition 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S, determined by the unique strategy, with its complement/inverse 𝒮 =ℳ\𝒮 𝒮\ℳ𝒮{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}={\mathcal{M}}\backslash{% \mathcal{S}}overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG = caligraphic_M \ caligraphic_S. Without loss of generality, let 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S be the smaller set of 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S and 𝒮  𝒮{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG, and 𝒮  𝒮{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG the larger. This will be useful in the remainder of the paper when we talk about coalition size as then |𝒮|≤⌊M/2⌋𝒮𝑀2|{\mathcal{S}}|\leq\lfloor M/2\rfloor| caligraphic_S | ≤ ⌊ italic_M / 2 ⌋, where ⌊⋅⌋⋅\lfloor\cdot\rfloor⌊ ⋅ ⌋ denotes the floor function. Conceptually, we only sample coalitions 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S with coalition indices less than or equal to 2M−1superscript2𝑀12^{M-1}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and then add their paired counterparts 𝒮  𝒮{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG with coalition indices larger than 2M−1superscript2𝑀12^{M-1}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The probability of sampling 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S is then p𝒮+p𝒮 =2⁢p𝒮subscript𝑝𝒮subscript𝑝 𝒮2subscript𝑝𝒮p_{\mathcal{S}}+p_{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}=2p_{% \mathcal{S}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2 italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where p𝒮subscript𝑝𝒮p_{\mathcal{S}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is given in (8). However, the doubling is redundant when normalizing the probabilities, as all coalitions have doubled their probability. Note that N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will always be an even number for the paired strategy. The paired strategy also stabilizes the sampling frequencies by ensuring that 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S and 𝒮  𝒮{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG always obtain the same weights, as seen in Figure 1. The weights are given by

3.3 Paired Average

This means that the stabilized weights w𝒮subscript𝑤𝒮w_{\mathcal{S}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are given by

The paired and paired average strategies are identical for coalition sizes where no coalition has been sampled more than once. The paired average sampling strategy is more stable and its weights tend faster to p𝒮subscript𝑝𝒮p_{\mathcal{S}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in (8) when N𝒮→2M→subscript𝑁𝒮superscript2𝑀N_{\mathcal{S}}\rightarrow 2^{M}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT than the unique and paired strategies; see Figure 1. To the best of our knowledge, the paired average strategy is a novel extension to the paired strategy.

A natural extension to reduce the variance of the weights w𝒮subscript𝑤𝒮w_{\mathcal{S}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT further is to repeat the sampling step B𝐵Bitalic_B times and use the empirical means of (11) as the new and more stable weights. We include this strategy in Appendix E and call it paired empirical. However, the performance is more or less identical to the paired c-kernel strategy, which we introduce below in Section 3.5.

3.4 Paired Kernel

As the weights of the paired average strategy tend to the normalized Shapley kernel weights p𝒮subscript𝑝𝒮p_{\mathcal{S}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT given in (8) and the exact Shapley value computations use these weights, a natural consideration is to also use these directly as weights when we approximate the Shapley values. In the paired kernel strategy, we sample the coalitions as in the paired strategy, but we let the weights be

w𝒮∝p𝒮.proportional-tosubscript𝑤𝒮subscript𝑝𝒮\displaystyle w_{\mathcal{S}}\propto p_{\mathcal{S}}.italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∝ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (12)

See Table 2 for the values of p𝒮subscript𝑝𝒮p_{\mathcal{S}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for some dimensionalities. Coalitions of equal size have the same weight in the paired kernel strategy. In Appendix B, we demonstrate and explore the relation between the paired average and paired kernel strategies.

3.5 Paired C-Kernel

The paired c-kernel strategy corrects the weights in the paired kernel strategy by conditioning on the coalitions being sampled at least once. For ease of understanding, we first explain the correction technique for the unique setting before we extend it to the paired setting, which is the one we use.

The unique strategy samples a sequence of L≥N𝒮𝐿subscript𝑁𝒮L\geq N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_L ≥ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT coalitions with replacements until N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT unique coalitions are obtained. The probability of sampling a coalition 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S with size |𝒮|𝒮|{\mathcal{S}}|| caligraphic_S | is p𝒮subscript𝑝𝒮p_{\mathcal{S}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT given by (8). In the paired kernel strategy, we directly use the p𝒮subscript𝑝𝒮p_{\mathcal{S}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT quantities as weights, but we do not condition on 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S being among the N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT uniquely sampled coalitions, which is additional information that naturally should be reflected in the weights. When we consider this, we get the corrected Shapley kernel weights

p~𝒮=p𝒮Pr⁡(𝒮 sampled at least once)=p𝒮1−Pr⁡(𝒮 not sampled)=p𝒮1−(1−p𝒮)L,subscript~𝑝𝒮subscript𝑝𝒮Pr𝒮 sampled at least oncesubscript𝑝𝒮1Pr𝒮 not sampledsubscript𝑝𝒮1superscript1subscript𝑝𝒮𝐿\displaystyle\tilde{p}_{\mathcal{S}}=\frac{p_{\mathcal{S}}}{\operatorname{Pr}(% \text{${\mathcal{S}}$ sampled at least once})}=\frac{p_{\mathcal{S}}}{1-% \operatorname{Pr}(\text{${\mathcal{S}}$ not sampled})}=\frac{p_{\mathcal{S}}}{% 1-(1-p_{\mathcal{S}})^{L}},over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_Pr ( caligraphic_S sampled at least once ) end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - roman_Pr ( caligraphic_S not sampled ) end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - ( 1 - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , (13)

which we normalize to sum to one over the non-trivial coalitions.

In Section 3.2, we discussed that paired sampling conceptually only samples coalitions 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S with coalition indices less than or equal to 2M−1superscript2𝑀12^{M-1}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and then add the paired 𝒮  𝒮{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG. Thus, the number of sampling steps L𝐿Litalic_L is halved while the corresponding probabilities become 2⁢p𝒮2subscript𝑝𝒮2p_{\mathcal{S}}2 italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that the normalization means that the two in the numerator in (14) and (15) is redundant.

The paired c-kernel strategy assigns equal weight to coalitions within the same coalition size and between paired coalition sizes |𝒮|𝒮|{\mathcal{S}}|| caligraphic_S | and |𝒮 |=M−|𝒮| 𝒮𝑀𝒮|{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}|=M-|{\mathcal{S}}|| overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG | = italic_M - | caligraphic_S |, as illustrated in Figure 1. Note that (15) is not a fully analytical expression, as we need to sample a sequence of coalitions to obtain L𝐿Litalic_L. However, there is no additional computational cost since sampling a subset of coalitions is already required when approximating Shapley values. Nevertheless, different L𝐿Litalic_L values are obtained each time due to the stochastic nature of the sampling process, which results in slightly different p~𝒮subscript~𝑝𝒮\tilde{p}_{{\mathcal{S}}}over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values, as represented by the confidence bands in Figure 2.

3.6 Paired CEL-Kernel

The paired cel-kernel strategy extends the paired c-kernel strategy by replacing L𝐿Litalic_L in (14) with the expected value 𝔼⁢[L]=𝔼⁢[L∣N𝒮⁢ unique coalitions]𝔼delimited-[]𝐿𝔼delimited-[]conditional𝐿subscript𝑁𝒮 unique coalitions\mathbb{E}[L]=\mathbb{E}[L\mid N_{\mathcal{S}}\text{ unique coalitions}]blackboard_E [ italic_L ] = blackboard_E [ italic_L ∣ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT unique coalitions ]. This removes the variability in the paired c-kernel strategy caused by the stochastic L𝐿Litalic_L. We use results related to the coupon collector’s problem \parenciteferrante2014coupon from combinatorial probability theory to obtain the theoretically expected number of samples L𝐿Litalic_L needed to obtain N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT unique coalitions.

For ease of understanding, we first introduce the results for the unique setting before we extend it to the paired setting. In the unique setting, we consider the coalitions to be coupons with non-uniform probabilities of being collected, and we want to collect a subset of the 2M−2superscript2𝑀22^{M}-22 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 coupons / non-trivial coalitions. This is a generalization of the classical coupon collector’s problem, which focuses on the expected number of draws it takes to collect all coupons when they have an equal probability of being collected. We propose a reformulation of (17) which drastically reduces the number of terms by grouping coalitions with equal probability together. To understand the importance of the group reformulation in (18), consider an example with M=10𝑀10M=10italic_M = 10 and q=255𝑞255q=255italic_q = 255. However, even with this reformulation, we cannot compute the exact expectations for M>10𝑀10M>10italic_M > 10 in a feasible time444For M=10𝑀10M=10italic_M = 10, it takes approximately 19191919 hours to compute (18) using 16 threads on an ARM Neoverse N1 with 512GB RAM. In contrast, simulating 1000100010001000 L𝐿Litalic_L values and computing their mean takes a few minutes using a single thread, with only minuscule differences in the results, see Figure 16 in Appendix C. Some of the long computation time can be attributed to the gmp package \parencitegmp, which is necessary to handle arbitrary precision arithmetic. The integer class in R cannot store large enough integers and the numeric class lacks sufficient precision, which leads to floating point errors that become significant when accumulated.. For M>10𝑀10M>10italic_M > 10, we simulate 1000100010001000 L𝐿Litalic_L values and use the empirical mean as an estimator, i.e., L¯=11000⁢∑l=11000Ll≈𝔼⁢[L]¯𝐿11000superscriptsubscript𝑙11000subscript𝐿𝑙𝔼delimited-[]𝐿\bar{L}=\tfrac{1}{1000}\sum_{l=1}^{1000}L_{l}\approx\mathbb{E}[L]over¯ start_ARG italic_L end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1000 end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1000 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≈ blackboard_E [ italic_L ].

We insert (18) into (14) to obtain the weights used by the paired cel-kernel strategy in (7) when approximating the Shapley value explanations, that is,

w𝒮∝2⁢p𝒮1−(1−2⁢p𝒮)𝔼⁢[L]/2.proportional-tosubscript𝑤𝒮2subscript𝑝𝒮1superscript12subscript𝑝𝒮𝔼delimited-[]𝐿2\displaystyle w_{\mathcal{S}}\propto\frac{2p_{\mathcal{S}}}{1-(1-2p_{\mathcal{% S}})^{\mathbb{E}[L]/2}}.italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∝ divide start_ARG 2 italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - ( 1 - 2 italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ italic_L ] / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG . (19)

For the sake of clarity, we stress that (19) does not yield 𝔼⁢[p~𝒮]𝔼delimited-[]subscript~𝑝𝒮\mathbb{E}[\tilde{p}_{{\mathcal{S}}}]blackboard_E [ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] as (14) is non-linear. However, inserting 𝔼⁢[L]𝔼delimited-[]𝐿\mathbb{E}[L]blackboard_E [ italic_L ] will act as a proxy to 𝔼⁢[p~𝒮]𝔼delimited-[]subscript~𝑝𝒮\mathbb{E}[\tilde{p}_{{\mathcal{S}}}]blackboard_E [ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], and in Figure 2, we illustrate that the difference is neglectable. There, the paired cel-kernel weights are illustrated by the dotted lines, while the 𝔼⁢[p~𝒮]𝔼delimited-[]subscript~𝑝𝒮\mathbb{E}[\tilde{p}_{{\mathcal{S}}}]blackboard_E [ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] weights are given by the solid curves. The paired cel-kernel weights accurately follow the 𝔼⁢[p~𝒮]𝔼delimited-[]subscript~𝑝𝒮\mathbb{E}[\tilde{p}_{{\mathcal{S}}}]blackboard_E [ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] weights and tend to the Shapley kernel weights when N𝒮→2M→subscript𝑁𝒮superscript2𝑀N_{\mathcal{S}}\rightarrow 2^{M}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We demonstrate the equal performance of the two versions in Appendix F. Note that we only include the weights for |𝒮|≤⌊M/2⌋𝒮𝑀2|{\mathcal{S}}|\leq\lfloor M/2\rfloor| caligraphic_S | ≤ ⌊ italic_M / 2 ⌋ in Figure 2 as we defined 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S to be the smaller one of 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S and 𝒮  𝒮{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG in Section 3.2. Additionally, the weights for the coalition sizes |𝒮|𝒮|{\mathcal{S}}|| caligraphic_S | (e.g., j𝑗jitalic_j) and |𝒮 | 𝒮|{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}|| overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG | (e.g., M−j𝑀𝑗M-jitalic_M - italic_j) are equal due to the symmetry of the paired sampling. Furthermore, the weights are independent of the model and explicands and only depend on the number of features M𝑀Mitalic_M. Thus, these weights can be precomputed, stored, and used when applicable.

3.7 Paired Imp C-Kernel

The paired imp c-kernel strategy extends the paired c-kernel strategy by including the most important paired coalitions, i.e., those with the largest Shapley kernel weights, first. This involves initially including coalitions 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S with one feature together with their complements 𝒮  𝒮{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG with M−1𝑀1M-1italic_M - 1 features, followed by coalitions with two features together with their complements with M−2𝑀2M-2italic_M - 2 features, and so on. We sample which coalitions to include in a paired manner for the coalition size where not all coalitions are included. That is, if N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is even, both 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S and its complement 𝒮  𝒮{\accentset{\rule{2.20503pt}{0.65pt}}{\mathcal{S}}}overOVERACCENT start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG are included, while only 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S is included when N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is odd.

For clarity, consider an example with M=10𝑀10M=10italic_M = 10 and N𝒮=25subscript𝑁𝒮25N_{\mathcal{S}}=25italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 25. The strategy first includes all size zero and one coalitions along with their paired complements, of which there are two and twenty coalitions, respectively. For the remaining three coalitions, we sample two coalitions uniformly (without replacement) from size-two coalitions, e.g., {1,2}12\{1,2\}{ 1 , 2 } and {5,9}59\{5,9\}{ 5 , 9 }. We then include the paired complement of the first sampled coalition, {3,4,5,6,7,8,9,10}345678910\{3,4,5,6,7,8,9,10\}{ 3 , 4 , 5 , 6 , 7 , 8 , 9 , 10 }, to reach the target of twenty-five coalitions. In Section E.3, we outline and discuss potential methods to include the coalitions based on pilot estimates of their importance instead of random sampling to improve the strategy.

The paired imp c-kernel strategy applies the Shapley kernel weight correction in (14) to obtain the weights w𝒮subscript𝑤𝒮w_{\mathcal{S}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT used in (7) when approximating Shapley values. However, the semi-deterministic inclusion method means that L=N𝒮𝐿subscript𝑁𝒮L=N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_L = italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the corresponding weights are therefore given by

w𝒮∝2⁢p𝒮1−(1−2⁢p𝒮)N𝒮/2.proportional-tosubscript𝑤𝒮2subscript𝑝𝒮1superscript12subscript𝑝𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮2\displaystyle w_{\mathcal{S}}\propto\frac{2p_{\mathcal{S}}}{1-(1-2p_{\mathcal{% S}})^{N_{\mathcal{S}}/2}}.italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∝ divide start_ARG 2 italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - ( 1 - 2 italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG . (20)

A consequence of the semi-deterministic inclusion is that the correction in (14) becomes invalid since it relies on the assumption that the sampling probability of coalition 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S is p𝒮subscript𝑝𝒮p_{\mathcal{S}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, (20) will not converge to the exact Shapley values when N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approaches 2Msuperscript2𝑀2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This is illustrated by the dashed curves in Figure 2 not converging to the dots, which represent the Shapley kernel weights.

3.8 Paired Imp CEL-Kernel

The paired imp cel-kernel strategy modifies the paired imp c-kernel strategy by replacing L=N𝒮𝐿subscript𝑁𝒮L=N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_L = italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in (20) with the expected value of L𝐿Litalic_L given in (18). That is, the modified weights are given by

w𝒮∝2⁢p𝒮1−(1−2⁢p𝒮)𝔼⁢[L]/2.proportional-tosubscript𝑤𝒮2subscript𝑝𝒮1superscript12subscript𝑝𝒮𝔼delimited-[]𝐿2\displaystyle w_{\mathcal{S}}\propto\frac{2p_{\mathcal{S}}}{1-(1-2p_{\mathcal{% S}})^{\mathbb{E}[L]/2}}.italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∝ divide start_ARG 2 italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - ( 1 - 2 italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ italic_L ] / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG . (21)

This adjustment ensures that the Shapley value approximations obtained by the paired imp cel-kernel strategy converges to the exact Shapley values when N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approaches 2Msuperscript2𝑀2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is illustrated by the black dotted curves in Figure 2 converging to the normalized Shapley kernel weights in (8).

4 Numerical Simulation Studies

A major problem in evaluating explanation frameworks is that real-world data has no true Shapley value explanations. In this section, we consider two setups where we simulate Gaussian data for which we can compute the true/exact Shapley values ϕbold-italic-ϕ{\boldsymbol{\phi}}bold_italic_ϕ using all 2Msuperscript2𝑀2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT coalitions. We then compare how close the approximated Shapley values ϕ𝒟subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝒟{\boldsymbol{\phi}}_{\mathcal{D}}bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are ϕbold-italic-ϕ{\boldsymbol{\phi}}bold_italic_ϕ using the different strategies and based on the coalitions in 𝒟⊂𝒫⁢(ℳ)𝒟𝒫ℳ{\mathcal{D}}\subset{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{M}})caligraphic_D ⊂ caligraphic_P ( caligraphic_M ). This paper does not focus on estimating the contribution functions v⁢(S)𝑣𝑆v(S)italic_v ( italic_S ) but on strategies for selecting the coalitions 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S. Thus, we compute the v⁢(𝒮)𝑣𝒮v({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) once using the gaussian approach in the shapr-package \parenciteshapr or analytical results, store them, and load the needed v⁢(𝒮)𝑣𝒮v({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) values for the sampling strategies.

The parameters 𝝁𝝁{\boldsymbol{\mu}}bold_italic_μ and 𝚺𝚺{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}bold_Σ are easily estimated using the sample mean and covariance matrix of the training data, respectively. However, we provide the true parameters to shapr to eliminate the uncertainty in estimating them and to obtain the true Shapley values.

We evaluate the performance of the sampling strategies by computing the averaged mean absolute error (MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE) between the exact (ϕbold-italic-ϕ{\boldsymbol{\phi}}bold_italic_ϕ) and approximated (ϕ𝒟subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝒟{\boldsymbol{\phi}}_{\mathcal{D}}bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) Shapley values, averaged over B𝐵Bitalic_B repetitions (different seeds), Nexplainsubscript𝑁explainN_{\text{explain}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT explain end_POSTSUBSCRIPT explicands, and M𝑀Mitalic_M features. A similar criterion has been used in \textciteredelmeier2020, aas2019explaining, aas2021explaining, Olsen2022, olsen2024comparative, olsen2023precision. The MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE is given by

MAE=MAE¯B⁢(ϕ,ϕ𝒟)=1B⁢∑b=1BMAEb=1B⁢∑b=1B1Nexplain⁢∑i=1Nexplain1M⁢∑j=1M|ϕi,j−ϕ𝒟b,i,j|.MAEsubscript¯MAE𝐵bold-italic-ϕsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝒟1𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝐵subscriptMAE𝑏1𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝐵1subscript𝑁explainsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑁explain1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑀subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕsubscript𝒟𝑏𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\operatorname{MAE}=\overline{\operatorname{MAE}}_{B}({\boldsymbol% {\phi}},{\boldsymbol{\phi}}_{\mathcal{D}})=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{b=1}^{B}% \operatorname{MAE}_{b}=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{b=1}^{B}\frac{1}{N_{\text{explain}}}% \sum_{i=1}^{N_{\text{explain}}}\frac{1}{M}\sum_{j=1}^{M}|\phi_{i,j}-\phi_{{% \mathcal{D}}_{b},i,j}|.roman_MAE = over¯ start_ARG roman_MAE end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ϕ , bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_MAE start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT explain end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT explain end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_M end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | . (22)

To speed up the computations, we recycle the sampled coalitions for strategies using the same sampling procedure. That is, the paired, paired average, paired kernel, paired c-kernel, and paired cel-kernel strategies all use the same sampling procedure before weighing the coalitions differently. Furthermore, the paired imp c-kernel and paired imp cel-kernel strategies also share their sampling procedure, while the unique strategy has a separate sampling procedure. To mitigate a separate sampling step for each increasing value of N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we sample a sequence/set of coalitions 𝒟𝒟{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D until all 2Msuperscript2𝑀2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT coalitions are included and keep track of at which index the sequence contains N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT unique coalitions. We can then efficiently “sample” the set 𝒟𝒟{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D with N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT unique coalitions by extracting the coalitions up to this index from the sequence. This is done for each of the B𝐵Bitalic_B repetitions.

Remark: The sampling step is more expensive for the first six strategies in Section 3 due to the repeated sampling with replacements. More precisely, the sampling procedure is time-consuming when N𝒮≈2Msubscript𝑁𝒮superscript2𝑀N_{\mathcal{S}}\approx 2^{M}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≈ 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and M𝑀Mitalic_M is large as the probability of sampling one of the N𝒮−|𝒟|subscript𝑁𝒮𝒟N_{\mathcal{S}}-|{\mathcal{D}}|italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - | caligraphic_D | remaining unique coalitions is minuscule and takes many iterations. For the paired sampling procedure in the M=20𝑀20M=20italic_M = 20-dimensional setting in Section 4.2, we sample on average L=80 738 405𝐿80738405L=80\,738\,405italic_L = 80 738 405 coalitions before we have 2M=1 048 576superscript2𝑀10485762^{M}=1\,048\,5762 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 048 576 unique coalitions. In Figure 15 in Appendix C, we plot the average L𝐿Litalic_L and E⁢[L]𝐸delimited-[]𝐿E[L]italic_E [ italic_L ] as functions of N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for different values of M𝑀Mitalic_M. In contrast, the sampling procedure used by the paired imp c-kernel and paired imp cel-kernel strategies is almost instantaneous due to direct sampling without replacement. For the paired kernel and paired cel-kernel strategies, which do not use the sampling frequencies or sequence length, we can speed up the sampling by listing all possible coalitions and conducting weighted sampling without replacements with p𝒮subscript𝑝𝒮p_{\mathcal{S}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (8) as sampling probabilities. However, listing all coalitions is impossible if M𝑀Mitalic_M is too large. When the coalitions in 𝒟𝒟{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D are determined, the computation of the approximated Shapley values in (7) is computed in the order of seconds as we load the stored v⁢(𝒮)𝑣𝒮v({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) values and do not have to compute them. In general, the computation of the contribution functions is often the most computationally demanding part \parenciteolsen2024comparative.

4.1 XGBoost Model

We fit a cross-validated xgboost model \parencitechen2015xgboost to this regression problem to act as the predictive model f𝑓fitalic_f. To obtain the true/exact Shapley values ϕbold-italic-ϕ{\boldsymbol{\phi}}bold_italic_ϕ, we use Monte Carlo integration with K=5000𝐾5000K=5000italic_K = 5000 Monte Carlo samples for each coalition and explicand. This is done using the gaussian approach in the shapr-package and the true Shapley values are illustrated with sina plots in Appendix D. We repeat the sampling strategies B=500𝐵500B=500italic_B = 500 times as they are stochastic.

In Figure 3, we plot the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE curves for the different strategies and dependence levels as a function of N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We also include 95%percent9595\%95 % empirical confidence bands to illustrate the uncertainty in the 500500500500 repeated experiments. Our novel strategies outperform the other established unique and paired sampling strategies for all dependence levels. The state-of-the-art paired strategy outperforms the unique strategy. Still, it is (almost) uniformly outperformed by our paired average, paired c-kernel, and paired cel-kernel strategies by a significant margin. This means that the simple weight-stabilizing technique in the paired average strategy lowers the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE values. However, the paired c-kernel strategy, which uses the corrected Shapley kernel weights instead of the stabilized sampling frequencies, gives additional improvements. Directly using the (uncorrected) Shapley kernel weights, as in the paired kernel strategy, yields poor approximations unless N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to 2Msuperscript2𝑀2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Finally, the paired cel-kernel strategy further improves the paired c-kernel strategy by lowering the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE scores by a small margin.

In general, our novel strategies improve the most upon the established paired strategy for the larger dependence levels, and the difference in the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE scores between the strategies increases when N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT increases. The paired c-kernel and paired cel-kernel strategies produce slightly more accurate Shapley value approximations than the paired average strategy. However, the difference is mainly noticeable for larger values of N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We discuss this difference more at the end of the section.

The paired imp c-kernel strategy performs very well for low values of N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, after including all coalitions up to size 3 (and their complements), the precision of the approximated Shapley values deteriorates, and the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE scores drastically increase. We do not have an explicit explanation for the location of the dip, and we include it as a part of further research in Section 6. However, the increase in the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE values when N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT tends to 2Msuperscript2𝑀2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is as expected and explained in Section 3.7. This behavior is corrected by the paired imp cel-kernel strategy.

The paired imp cel-kernel strategy is the best strategy in the simulation study and is on par with or outperforms all other strategies. It is only marginally outperformed by the paired average and paired c-kernel strategies for low values of N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that the paired imp cel-kernel strategy tends to obtain increased precision when it includes all coalitions of the same size, i.e., the dips in the curves at the dashed vertical lines in Figure 3. The dips are very evident for higher dependence levels. The paired kernel strategy outperforms the paired strategy for larger values of N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Still, it is never at the same precision level as the paired average, paired c-kernel, paired cel-kernel, and paired imp cel-kernel strategies.

The MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE values should be interpreted together with f𝑓fitalic_f to better understand the scale of the errors. Recall the efficiency axiom which states that f⁢(𝒙∗)=ϕ0+∑j=1Mϕj∗𝑓superscript𝒙subscriptitalic-ϕ0superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑀superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑗f(\boldsymbol{x}^{*})=\phi_{0}+\sum_{j=1}^{M}\phi_{j}^{*}italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. That is, the Shapley values explain the difference between ϕ0subscriptitalic-ϕ0\phi_{0}italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the predicted response f⁢(𝒙∗)𝑓superscript𝒙f(\boldsymbol{x}^{*})italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for different explicands 𝒙∗superscript𝒙\boldsymbol{x}^{*}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In Figure 4, we plot histograms of the f⁢(𝒙∗)𝑓superscript𝒙f(\boldsymbol{x}^{*})italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) values together with the corresponding ϕ0subscriptitalic-ϕ0\phi_{0}italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values for the four dependence levels. If the difference between ϕ0subscriptitalic-ϕ0\phi_{0}italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and f⁢(𝒙∗)𝑓superscript𝒙f(\boldsymbol{x}^{*})italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is small, then the Shapley values are often small too; we illustrate this for the real-world data set in Section 5. Thus, obtaining a low absolute error is easier for explicands with a predicted response closer to ϕ0subscriptitalic-ϕ0\phi_{0}italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

In the simulation studies, we have that 1Nexplain⁢∑i=1Nexplain|ϕ0−f⁢(𝒙∗)|1subscript𝑁explainsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑁explainsubscriptitalic-ϕ0𝑓superscript𝒙\frac{1}{N_{\text{explain}}}\sum_{i=1}^{N_{\text{explain}}}|\phi_{0}-f(% \boldsymbol{x}^{*})|divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT explain end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT explain end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | equals 11.5411.5411.5411.54, 12.2712.2712.2712.27, 13.0213.0213.0213.02, 15.9815.9815.9815.98 for the four dependence levels ρ∈{0,0.2,0.5,0.9}𝜌00.20.50.9\rho\in\{0,0.2,0.5,0.9\}italic_ρ ∈ { 0 , 0.2 , 0.5 , 0.9 }, respectively. In Figure 6, we illustrate the reduction in N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT when using the paired c-kernel strategy to achieve the same MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE scores as the unique and paired strategies. In Figure 5, we plot the relative difference in MAE=MAE¯500⁢(ϕ,ϕ𝒟)MAEsubscript¯MAE500bold-italic-ϕsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝒟\operatorname{MAE}=\overline{\operatorname{MAE}}_{500}({\boldsymbol{\phi}},{% \boldsymbol{\phi}}_{\mathcal{D}})roman_MAE = over¯ start_ARG roman_MAE end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 500 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ϕ , bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) values obtained by the paired average, paired c-kernel, and paired cel-kernel strategies when using the paired c-kernel strategy as the reference. The relative difference is included to more easily distinguish the performance of these strategies, as their confidence bands in Figure 3 overlap and are difficult to separate. In Figure 5, we observe that, on average, the paired cel-kernel strategy obtains a lower relative error compared to paired c-kernel, whereas the paired average obtains a higher relative error. The solid confidence bands show that the average relative error is significantly different between the strategies, especially when N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT increases. However, the somewhat overlapping dashed confidence bands tell us that the order of the strategies can be different for some of the B𝐵Bitalic_B repetitions. In practice, the absolute difference in the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE scores between these strategies is minuscule and is unlikely to have any consequential practical implications.

4.2 Linear Regression Model

In the second simulation study, we investigate a larger dimensional setup. However, we are limited by the computational complexity of the true Shapley values growing exponentially with the number of features. Thus, we settle on an M=20𝑀20M=20italic_M = 20-dimensional Gaussian data setup with a linear model as the predictive model f𝑓fitalic_f, as we can then obtain analytical expressions for the contribution function \parencite[Appendix B.2]aas2019explaining. 5 Real-World Data Experiments

We consider the Red Wine data set from the UCI Machine Learning Repository to evaluate the sampling strategies on real non-Gaussian data. We fit a cross-validated random forest model666A ranger model \parenciteranger with trees=200trees200\texttt{trees}=200trees = 200, mtry=4mtry4\texttt{mtry}=4mtry = 4, and min.node.size=3min.node.size3\texttt{min.node.size}=3min.node.size = 3. to act as the predictive model. We compute the Shapley values ϕbold-italic-ϕ{\boldsymbol{\phi}}bold_italic_ϕ using the random forest separate regression approach in the shapr package777See the regression vignette for an introduction to the random forest separate regression approach.. \textciteolsen2024comparative determined this approach to yield the most precise Shapley values for this data set and predictive model. The approach estimates (2) by a random forest model with default hyperparameter values: trees=500trees500\texttt{trees}=500trees = 500, mtry=3mtry3\texttt{mtry}=3mtry = 3, and min.node.size=5min.node.size5\texttt{min.node.size}=5min.node.size = 5. We compare these Shapley values ϕbold-italic-ϕ{\boldsymbol{\phi}}bold_italic_ϕ using all 2Msuperscript2𝑀2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT coalitions with the approximated Shapley values ϕ𝒟subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝒟{\boldsymbol{\phi}}_{\mathcal{D}}bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT obtained by using only N𝒮=|𝒟|subscript𝑁𝒮𝒟N_{\mathcal{S}}=|{\mathcal{D}}|italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = | caligraphic_D | unique coalitions determined by the different sampling strategies.

The Red Wine data set contains information about variants of the Portuguese Vinho Verde wine \parencitecortez2009using. The response is a quality value between 00 and 10101010, while the M=11𝑀11M=11italic_M = 11 continuous features are based on physicochemical tests: fixed acidity, volatile acidity, citric acid, residual sugar, chlorides, free sulfur dioxide, total sulfur dioxide, density, pH, sulphates, and alcohol. For the Red Wine data set, most scatter plots and marginal density functions display structures and marginals far from the Gaussian distribution, as most of the marginals are right-skewed \parencite[Figure S10]olsen2024comparative. Many features have no to moderate correlation, with a mean absolute correlation of 0.200.200.200.20, while the largest correlation in absolute value is 0.6830.6830.6830.683 between pH and fix_acid. The data set contains 1599159915991599 wines, and we split it into a training (1500150015001500) and a test (99999999) data set.

6 Conclusion and Further Work

A major drawback of the Shapley value explanation framework is its computational complexity, which grows exponentially with the number of features. The KernelSHAP approximation framework addresses this by approximating Shapley values as the solution to a weighted least squares problem using a sampled subset 𝒟𝒟{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D of the 2Msuperscript2𝑀2^{M}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT coalitions \parencitelundberg2017unified. We introduce several novel strategies for selecting 𝒟𝒟{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D and weighing its N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT unique elements. Our paired average strategy extends the state-of-the-art paired strategy \parencitecovert2021improving within the KernelSHAP framework by pairing not only the sampling frequencies of paired coalitions but also within the different coalition sizes. By averaging the sampling frequencies within each coalition size, we ensure faster and more stable convergence to the Shapley kernel weights. The novel paired c-kernel strategy directly utilizes the Shapley kernel weights but corrects them based on the sampled subset. While the paired cel-kernel strategy takes the expectation over the subset to remove the variance and produce deterministic weights. The paired imp c-kernel and paired imp cel-kernel strategies determine the subset of coalitions in a semi-deterministic way by including the most important coalitions first.

Through simulation studies and real-world data examples, we demonstrate that our strategies lead to uniformly more accurate Shapley value explanations using fewer coalitions than competing strategies. More specifically, the paired strategy is consistently outperformed by the paired average strategy, which in turn is outperformed by the paired c-kernel strategy. The more complex paired cel-kernel strategy outperforms the paired c-kernel strategy. However, the difference is negligible and unlikely to affect practical applications. The paired imp c-kernel and paired imp cel-kernel strategies, especially the latter, produce the most accurate Shapley value approximations of all strategies within certain ranges of N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values, but it is often significantly worse outside these regions. Identifying these regions in advance is challenging. Based on our simulation studies and experiments, we recommend the paired c-kernel strategy for its simplicity and consistently high accuracy.

We identify four potential areas for further research. First, we can develop a deeper understanding of when and why the paired imp c-kernel and paired imp cel-kernel strategies perform well. This analysis should explore whether certain data properties or model characteristics influence their effectiveness. Second, we may extend and enhance our strategies by guiding the sampling of coalitions toward more informative coalitions using pilot estimates. We outline preliminary work on this idea in Appendix E. Third, we can theoretically prove the variance reduction properties of, e.g., the paired average and paired c-kernel strategies, similar to the proof provided by \textcite[Theorem 1.]covert2021improving for the paired strategy. Additionally, investigate whether these weighting schemes are optimal or if better alternatives can be discovered. In a smaller-dimensional setup, one can consider brute force to see if we can find another set of better weights. We can then use the findings to build intuition and extend it to higher dimensions and theoretical results. Fourth, we can compare our strategies with those proposed for other Shapley value approximation frameworks beyond KernelSHAP. For instance, strategies for the random order value formulation have been proposed by \textcitemitchell2022sampling, van2018new, illes2019estimation, castro2017improving. Notably, \textcitemitchell2022sampling find that a paired sampling strategy achieves near-best convergence compared to more complex alternatives. Additionally, comparisons could include the projected gradient descent strategy by \textcitesimon2020projected or the amortized explanation model by \textcitefastshap, which uses a neural network to directly output approximated Shapley values for classification problems.

The main computational burden of approximating Shapley values lies in estimating the contribution function values v⁢(𝒮)𝑣𝒮v({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) rather than sampling and determining the weights of the coalitions 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S. Therefore, our proposed strategies, which reduce the number of unique coalitions N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT while maintaining the accuracy of the approximated Shapley values, are very computationally beneficial. For example, we approximately halve the computation cost and time when we halve the number of coalitions. In Figure 6, we illustrate the reduction in N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT when using the paired c-kernel strategy to achieve the same accuracy as the unique and paired strategies. The paired c-kernel strategy reduces the required number of coalitions by 50%percent5050\%50 % to 95%percent9595\%95 % compared to the unique strategy and by 25%percent2525\%25 % to 50%percent5050\%50 % compared to the paired strategy, depending on N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the dependence level between the features. This substantial decrease significantly lowers the computational cost and time for Shapley value explanations, making them more feasible in practical applications.

Appendix

In Appendix A, we describe the implementation details. The link between the paired average and paired kernel strategies are discussed in Appendix B, while the corrected kernel weights are elaborated in Appendix C. Appendix D provides sina plots of the Shapley values computed in the main article. Additional sampling strategies are introduced and evaluated in Appendix E. In Appendix F, we compare the paired cel-kernel and paired ceps-kernel strategies. In Appendix G, we demonstrate that our novel techniques can significantly enhance the strategy used in the SHAP Python library.

Appendix A Implementation Details

We use version 0.2.3.9200 of the shapr-package in R available on GitHub \parenciteshapr as a code foundation. In this version, the only sampling strategy in the package is the unique strategy from Section 3.1. We have implemented the other strategies introduced in Sections 3.2, 3.3, 3.4, 3.5, 3.6 and 3.7 and Appendix E. To generate the true contribution functions and Shapley values in Section 4.1, we have used the gaussian approach in shapr with K=5000𝐾5000K=5000italic_K = 5000 Monte Carlo Samples from the true Gaussian data distribution. While we used explicit formulas for the contribution function in Section 4.2. In Section 5, we used the random forest separate regression approach introduced in \textciteolsen2024comparative to compute the contribution functions. For the pilot estimates in Appendix E, we use the linear model separate regression approach introduced in \textciteolsen2024comparative due to its rapid computations. We run the code on a shared computer server running Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.5. The server has two Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6226R CPU@2.90GHz (16 cores, 32 threads each) and 768GB DDR4 RAM. Since the memory usage is limited, all simulations can be run on a desktop computer, but at cost of increased elapsed time. Computing the exact Shapley values are the most computational demanding.

Appendix B From Paired Average to Paired Kernel

In Figure 13, we illustrate that the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE curves corresponding to the paired average strategy converges (and worsens) to the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE curves corresponding to the paired kernel strategy when we continue to sample coalitions. That is, we sample the chosen N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT unique coalitions an additional L𝐿Litalic_L times to make the corresponding sampling frequencies more accurate estimates of the Shapley kernel weights. We observe a gradual increase in the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE when we increase L𝐿Litalic_L. This demonstrates that the stabilized sampling frequencies are better weights than the Shapley kernel weights when approximating Shapley values using the KernelSHAP framework.

Appendix D Sina Plots of the Shapley Values

In Sections 4 and 5, we discussed that the MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE scores have to be interpreted in connection to the magnitude of the Shapley values/function f𝑓fitalic_f, and we used averages to pinpoint what we considered a low MAEMAE\operatorname{MAE}roman_MAE. In this section, we provide sina plots, also called beeswarm plots, to illustrate the different scales of the Shapley values; hence, using averages gives a rough estimate. In Figures 18, 17 and 19, we include sina plots of the Shapley values ϕbold-italic-ϕ{\boldsymbol{\phi}}bold_italic_ϕ in the simulation studies and examples in Sections 4.1, 4.2 and 5. For the simulation studies, we see that the magnitude of the Shapley values for X1subscript𝑋1X_{1}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, X7subscript𝑋7X_{7}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 7 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and X15subscript𝑋15X_{15}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are larger than the other features, which makes sense due to their larger coefficients compared to the other features in the data generating processes. We also see that the Shapley values are more evenly distributed among the features for larger feature dependencies, a well-known property of the conditional Shapley value framework \parencitechen2020true.

Appendix E Additional Sampling Strategies

We have investigated more sampling strategies than those discussed in Section 3, but we excluded them due to their very similar or generally poor performance. However, for the sake of completeness, we provide an overview of the strategies in Section E.1 and we elaborate on the two piloted strategies in Sections E.2 and E.3. In Section E.4, we compare and evaluate the strategies on the same experiments as in Sections 4 and 5.

E.1 Sampling Strategies: Overview

In this section, we provide an overview of the additional sampling strategies that we explored and we split them into two lists. In the first list, we introduce the additional strategies whose results we include in Section E.4, while the second list contains the strategies that are excluded due to their poor performance. The strategies ending with kernel and empirical use the Shapley kernel weights (Section 3.4) and the empirical mean sampling frequencies (explained below), respectively.

  1. Paired empirical:

    The paired empirical strategy extends the paired average strategy by repeating the sampling step to obtain a more stable estimate of the weights for each coalition size, i.e., reduce their variance. That is, we repeat the sampling procedure 250250250250 times and use the empirical means as the new weights. This extra sampling step is independent of the model and explicands and only depends on the number of features. Thus, these weights can be precomputed, stored, and used when applicable. This strategy performs very similar to the paired c-kernel and paired cel-kernel strategies.

  2. Paired largest empirical:

    The paired largest empirical strategy uses the empirical mean weights introduced by the paired empirical strategy but rather includes paired coalitions based on their weights in decreasing order, as the paired imp c-kernel strategy in Section 3.7. This strategy performs very similar to the paired imp cel-kernel strategy.

  3. Paired largest kernel:

    This strategy is equivalent to the paired largest empirical strategy except for using the Shapley kernel weights instead of the empirical mean sampling frequencies. That is, we add the coalitions with the largest Shapley kernel weights first in increasing order and paired manner. Then we sample coalitions with uniform probability for the coalition size where not all coalitions are included.

  4. Paired largest order kernel:

    Identical to the paired largest kernel strategy except that we rather add the coalitions in order and paired manner for coalition sizes where not all coalitions are included. To elaborate, in the example given in Section 3.7, the latter three coalitions would be {1,2,3}123\{1,2,3\}{ 1 , 2 , 3 }, the pair {4,5,6,7,8,9,10}45678910\{4,5,6,7,8,9,10\}{ 4 , 5 , 6 , 7 , 8 , 9 , 10 }, and {1,2,4}124\{1,2,4\}{ 1 , 2 , 4 }. Then we use the Shapley kernel weights.

  5. Paired largest order empirical:

    Identical to the paired largest order kernel strategy except that we use the empirical mean sampling frequencies as the weights.

  6. Pilot average:

    Identical to the paired average strategy except that we sample the coalitions using the piloted importance weights for each coalition introduced in Section E.2 instead of using the Shapley kernel weights. This means that the distribution of the stabilized sampling frequencies will not tend to the Shapley kernel weights, and the strategy will give inaccurate approximations when N𝒮→2M→subscript𝑁𝒮superscript2𝑀N_{\mathcal{S}}\to 2^{M}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  7. Pilot empirical:

    Identical to the pilot average strategy except that we replace the sampling frequencies at the end with the empirical mean sampling frequencies. Conceptually, this ensures that we sample important coalitions but weigh them such that we obtain the exact Shapley values when N𝒮→2M→subscript𝑁𝒮superscript2𝑀N_{\mathcal{S}}\to 2^{M}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  8. Pilot largest kernel:

    We add the coalitions based on the order of importance based on the pilot estimates and then use the Shapley kernel weights. That is, no sampling is conducted.

  9. Pilot largest empirical:

    Identical to the pilot largest kernel strategy except that we use the empirical mean sampling frequencies as the weights.

  10. MAD largest kernel:

    Identical to the paired largest kernel strategy except that instead of sampling the remaining coalitions, we use the procedure outlined in Section E.3 to determine the most important coalitions and include them based on the order of importance. Then we use the Shapley kernel weights.

  11. MAD largest empirical:

    Identical to the MAD largest kernel strategy except that we use the empirical mean sampling frequencies as the weights.

We now present the strategies not included in Section E.4 as they performed poorly.

  1. Order increasing kernel:

    Add coalitions based on the ordering introduced in the Section 3. That is, we add all coalitions of size one, then size two, and so on.

  2. Order decreasing kernel:

    Add coalitions based on the reverse ordering introduced in the Section 3. That is, we add all coalitions of size M−1𝑀1M-1italic_M - 1, then size M2subscript𝑀2M_{2}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and so on.

  3. Paired smallest kernel:

    Add coalitions with the smallest Shapley kernel weights first in decreasing order and paired manner. I.e., the reverse order of the paired largest kernel strategy.

  4. Largest coalition kernel:

    Add the coalitions with the largest Shapley kernel weights first but in increasing coalition size (i.e., no paired sampling). E.g., for M=4𝑀4M=4italic_M = 4, we would add the coalitions in the following order: {1}1\left\{1\right\}{ 1 }, {2}2\left\{2\right\}{ 2 }, {3}3\left\{3\right\}{ 3 }, {4}4\left\{4\right\}{ 4 }, {1,2,3}123\left\{1,2,3\right\}{ 1 , 2 , 3 }, {1,2,4}124\left\{1,2,4\right\}{ 1 , 2 , 4 }, {1,3,4}134\left\{1,3,4\right\}{ 1 , 3 , 4 }, {2,3,4}234\left\{2,3,4\right\}{ 2 , 3 , 4 }, {1,2}12\left\{1,2\right\}{ 1 , 2 }, {1,3}13\left\{1,3\right\}{ 1 , 3 }, {1,4}14\left\{1,4\right\}{ 1 , 4 }, {2,3}23\left\{2,3\right\}{ 2 , 3 }, {2,4}24\left\{2,4\right\}{ 2 , 4 }, and {3,4}34\left\{3,4\right\}{ 3 , 4 }.

  5. Smallest coalition kernel:

    Add the coalitions with the smallest Shapley kernel weights first but in decreasing coalition size (i.e., no paired sampling). I.e., the reverse order of the largest coalition kernel strategy.

E.2 Sampling Strategies: Pilot

The pilot strategies are motivated by the fact that some coalitions often are more critical than others in the Shapley value computations. Thus, we should include these coalitions when approximating the Shapley values. The strategies in Section 3 sample the coalitions only based on the coalition size |𝒮|𝒮|{\mathcal{S}}|| caligraphic_S | and do not take v⁢(𝒮)𝑣𝒮v({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) into consideration (as they are not available). We propose to compute (rough) pilot estimates v~⁢(S)~𝑣𝑆\tilde{v}(S)over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG ( italic_S ) of v⁢(𝒮)𝑣𝒮v({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) and include these in the sampling procedure. We use a linear regression model to estimate v⁢(𝒮)𝑣𝒮v({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ), i.e., the linear model separate regression approach in \textciteolsen2024comparative. This approach was chosen for its low computational cost.

It is conceptually possible that all coalitions are important for some combinations of features and explicands. However, this is not optimal as we want to limit the number of coalitions 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S to compute v⁢(𝒮)𝑣𝒮v({\mathcal{S}})italic_v ( caligraphic_S ) for. Thus, we average across the features and explicands to determine the N𝒮subscript𝑁𝒮N_{\mathcal{S}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT most important coalitions on average and use those for all features and explicands.
